Introduction

Atypical antidepressants are medications that have different mechanisms of action than the 4 main classes of antidepressants (ie, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors [SSRIs], serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors [SNRIs], tricyclic antidepressants [TCAs], and monoamine oxidase inhibitors [MAOIs]).  Atypical antidepressants include bupropion and mirtazapine; the serotonin modulators trazodone, vilazodone, and vortioxetine; the NMDA receptor antagonists ketamine and esketamine; as well as the neuroactive steroids, zuranolone and brexanolone.  They all vary in pharmacologic properties, clinical indications, and safety profile.

Bupropion

Pharmacology



Bupropion inhibits reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine at neuronal synapses and enhances noradrenergic and dopaminergic neurotransmission.  Bupropion has minimal serotonergic activity, distinguishing it from most other antidepressants.



By enhancing dopamine neurotransmission in the nucleus accumbens, bupropion attenuates nicotine withdrawal symptoms in those who use nicotine, reducing cravings.



Bupropion's molecular structure is related to amphetamines and may result in false-positive results on drug screens for amphetamines.

Indications



Bupropion is used to treat:



  • major depressive disorder (MDD)
  • seasonal affective disorder (SAD)
  • smoking cessation (used to reduce nicotine cravings)


The efficacy of bupropion in treating depression is similar to that of SSRIs.  Bupropion can be used as monotherapy as well as an adjunct medication with an SSRI.  Its stimulating properties make it useful for those who struggle with fatigue and hypersomnia.



Bupropion is not associated with significant sexual dysfunction or weight gain, which are potential adverse effects of SSRIs.  Adjunctive bupropion may even improve sexual function in those with SSRI-associated sexual dysfunction.  Bupropion typically does not have significant withdrawal symptoms upon discontinuation.



In addition, the combination of bupropion with dextromethorphan is used to treat MDD.  The combination of bupropion with naltrexone is used as an appetite suppressant for weight loss.

Adverse effects 



Common adverse effects of bupropion include dry mouth, nausea, insomnia, and weight loss.



Bupropion reduces the seizure threshold, especially at higher doses.  Avoid using bupropion in patients with significant risk factors for having seizures, such as epilepsy, anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, alcohol or benzodiazepine withdrawal, and traumatic brain injury.



Bupropion is contraindicated within 14 days of any MAOI use, because concurrent use increases the risk of hypertensive crisis due to MAOIs irreversibly binding MAO.



Overdose of bupropion may have life-threatening effects, such as seizures and cardiac toxicity (eg, QT prolongation, ventricular tachycardia, cardiac arrest).

Mirtazapine

Pharmacology



Mirtazapine antagonizes presynaptic alpha-2 adrenergic receptors, increasing serotonin and norepinephrine neurotransmission.  This is a unique mechanism to promote the activity of these neurotransmitters compared with reuptake inhibition seen in other antidepressant classes (eg, SSRIs).  Mirtazapine also antagonizes 5-HT2 and 5-HT3 receptors, which can result in decreased anxiety and increased appetite, as well as histamine receptors, leading to its sedative effects.

Indications



Mirtazapine is used to treat MDD and can be used as monotherapy or an adjunct medication.



Due to its sedative and appetite-stimulating properties, mirtazapine can be useful for patients with depression who have insomnia and/or decreased appetite.  Another advantage of mirtazapine is its lack of sexual dysfunction.



Mirtazapine alleviates nausea and diarrhea due to its effects on 5-HT3 receptors and may be an option for those who have struggled with gastrointestinal distress from other antidepressant classes.  It is often used in palliative care settings to aid with low mood, poor appetite, and insomnia.

Adverse effects 



Common adverse effects include sedation, increased appetite, weight gain, hypercholesterolemia, and dry mouth.



There is a risk of serotonin syndrome, particularly when combined with other serotonergic agents.  Mirtazapine is contraindicated within 14 days of any MAOI use, because concurrent use increases the risk of hypertensive crisis due to MAOIs irreversibly binding MAO.

Serotonin modulators

Trazodone

Pharmacology



Trazodone primarily antagonizes postsynaptic serotonin 5-HT2A and 5-HT2C receptors and weakly inhibits presynaptic serotonin reuptake.  Trazodone also antagonizes alpha-1 adrenergic and histamine receptors, contributing to its sedative properties.

Indications



Trazodone at higher doses can be used to treat MDD, but this can often be difficult to tolerate due to increased sedating effects.  More commonly, trazodone is prescribed at lower doses for insomnia.

Adverse effects



Common adverse effects include sedation, dizziness, orthostatic hypotension, dry mouth, and blurred vision.  Abrupt discontinuation of trazodone can result in gastrointestinal distress, anxiety, and insomnia.



Priapism, a painful erection lasting >4 hours and unrelated to sexual stimulation, is a rare and serious adverse effect of trazodone and requires immediate medical attention (

Trazodone may also cause arrhythmias or QT prolongation, especially in individuals with preexisting heart conditions or those prescribed other QT-prolonging drugs.



Orthostatic hypotension is also a risk, so caution is advised when prescribing for elderly patients at risk for falls.



Serotonin syndrome, particularly when trazodone is combined with other serotonergic agents, can occur.  Trazodone is contraindicated within 14 days of any MAOI use, because concurrent use increases the risk of hypertensive crisis due to MAOIs irreversibly binding MAO.

Vilazodone

Pharmacology



Vilazodone inhibits presynaptic reuptake of serotonin and is a partial agonist at postsynaptic 5-HT1A receptors.

Indications



Vilazodone is used to treat MDD and is associated with a lower risk for sexual dysfunction compared with SSRIs.

Adverse effects



The safety profile is similar to SSRIs, including gastrointestinal distress (eg, diarrhea, nausea).



There is a risk of serotonin syndrome, particularly when combined with other serotonergic agents.  Vilazodone is contraindicated within 14 days of any MAOI use, because concurrent use increases the risk of hypertensive crisis due to MAOIs irreversibly binding MAO.

Vortioxetine

Pharmacology



Vortioxetine inhibits presynaptic reuptake of serotonin and has effects on multiple serotonin receptors, including 5-HT3 antagonism.  These actions influence serotonin transmission in complex ways, resulting in increased levels of acetylcholine, dopamine, and norepinephrine.

Indication



Vortioxetine is used to treat MDD and appears to improve cognitive dysfunction in depressed patients, which may be due to its effects on multiple neurotransmitters.  It also has a lower risk for sexual dysfunction compared with SSRIs.

Adverse effects



The safety profile is similar to SSRIs, including gastrointestinal distress (eg, diarrhea, nausea).



There is a risk of serotonin syndrome, particularly when combined with other serotonergic agents.  Vortioxetine is contraindicated within 14 days of any MAOI use, because concurrent use increases the risk of hypertensive crisis due to MAOIs irreversibly binding monoamine oxidase (MAO).

NMDA receptor antagonists: ketamine and esketamine

Pharmacology



Ketamine is an NMDA receptor antagonist and opioid receptor agonist.  It consists of a mixture of molecules that are enantiomers (non-superimposable mirror images), R-ketamine and S-ketamine.  While initially used as an anesthetic agent, intravenous ketamine was found to have rapid antidepressant effects, which led to the development of esketamine, an intranasal medication used for treatment-resistant depression.



Esketamine consists of isolated S-ketamine, which binds more potently to NMDA receptors compared with R-ketamine.  The mechanism of esketamine's antidepressant effect remains unclear, though its NMDA antagonism may improve mood by downstream effects on neuroplasticity (eg, upregulation of brain-derived neurotrophic factor [BDNF]) and increased glutamate neurotransmission.

Indications



Intranasal esketamine is used for treatment-resistant depression, typically in conjunction with an oral antidepressant.  Esketamine uniquely provides rapid relief of depressive symptoms, with response seen within 2-4 hours, whereas most other antidepressant agents take several weeks for effect.  It can be especially useful for quickly alleviating acute suicidal ideation.  However, long-term efficacy is unclear.



Esketamine is typically given twice weekly for 1 month and then gradually tapered off to once every 1-2 weeks for maintenance treatment.

Adverse effects



Common adverse effects include dissociation, dizziness, nausea, and sedation.  Esketamine can stimulate the release of catecholamines, so elevated blood pressure may also occur.  These adverse effects can be significant but typically resolve quickly.



Ketamine is a controlled substance and has the potential for misuse and dependence.  Esketamine must be administered in a supervised clinic setting, where patients are observed for adverse effects and their vital signs are routinely monitored â‰¥2 hours after administration.

Neuroactive steroids: zuranolone and brexanolone

Pharmacology



Zuranolone and brexanolone, which are used for postpartum depression, are neuroactive steroids mimicking allopregnanolone, a metabolite of progesterone.  They are positive allosteric modulators of GABA A receptors.



During pregnancy, there is a rise in allopregnanolone levels that is followed by an abrupt decline after delivery.  Sensitivity to this abrupt decrease in allopregnanolone as well as deficient GABA A receptor function have been implicated in postpartum depression.  By mimicking allopregnanolone and enhancing GABA A receptor activity, zuranolone and brexanolone help alleviate postpartum depression symptoms.



Zuranolone is an oral medication taken once daily for 14 days.  Brexanolone is an intravenous infusion given over the course of 60 hours, which may be more challenging to administer during the postpartum period.

Indications



Zuranolone and brexanolone are used to treat severe major depression in postpartum patients.  A unique advantage is their quicker antidepressant effect.  Benefits can typically be seen as early as 3 days.

Adverse effects



The most common adverse effect of zuranolone and brexanolone is excessive sedation.  Patients should be warned to avoid driving or other potentially dangerous activities for at least 12 hours after taking zuranolone.  It is a controlled substance and has the potential for misuse and dependence.

Selecting an atypical antidepressant



Consider an atypical antidepressant based on their safety profile and utility in specific patient populations (eg, treatment-resistant depression, postpartum women).  They are useful as alternate agents after experiencing adverse effects (eg, sexual dysfunction) from SSRIs or SNRIs.



  • Bupropion:  depressed patients with sexual dysfunction or weight gain concerns
  • Mirtazapine:  depressed patients with insomnia or poor appetite
  • Trazodone:  depressed patients with insomnia
  • Vilazodone:  depressed patients with sexual dysfunction
  • Vortioxetine:  depressed patients with cognitive dysfunction and/or sexual dysfunction
  • Esketamine:  rapid reduction in severe depressive symptoms and suicidality
  • Zuranolone and brexanolone:  postpartum depression

Summary



Atypical antidepressants have different mechanisms of action than the 4 main classes of antidepressants (ie, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors [SSRIs], serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors [SNRIs], tricyclic antidepressants [TCAs], and monoamine oxidase inhibitors [MAOIs]).  Atypical antidepressants may be preferred due to their unique pharmacologic properties and clinical indications.
